I did. I remember it being advertised like fuck back in the early 90s on TV but I had no idea what the movie was even about back then. The ads mostly focused on "Hey, look how sexy this cartoon woman is" without explaining much and mostly trying to show off the animation. I recall one of the ad spots being in the middle of The Simpsons and Holli addressing Bart directly during the commercial.

Years later I found out that it was a mix of animation with live action similar to Roger Rabbit and that made me interested enough to go watch it.

The movie was complete shit however. The plot largely makes no sense, is full of contrived convivences that pray you don't think about them too hard, half the "cartoon with live action" scenes are just an animation overlaid over live action that makes no sense whatsoever and feels there just to be there, even when it's trying to explain itself it barely explains itself (e.g. a scene where one of the human characters tries to explain to another human that his fountain pen is an incredibly dangerous weapon in the cartoon world by... spraying ink into a drunk cartoon character's mouth making him even more drunk. How this is supposed to explain how it's dangerous I have no idea), is full of animation blunders like characters talking with their mouths not moving, and pulls a "happy ending" out of it's ass in the last minute by making up a rule about the cartoon world that apparently not even any of the cartoon main characters except for the one explaining it realized was a thing... that again also only works as a happy ending if you don't think about it too hard.

Supposedly it's heavily butchered from what the original creator intended the movie to be like but I have no proof of that other than random YouTube videos on the subject, still feels like even if that is true and it was done how the creator wanted it would have been a mess though.

It tries to capture the look of the movie. With all the mismatched cartoon styles. Cool World is like a doodle/ graffiti world, the main character calls them 'Doodles' in the movie. Holli's origin is from some prison inmate comic book. There's a girl who was originally graffiti on some wall. So it has a clashing art style, and the game tries to imitate that. But despite the presentation of the game, its a bit of a jank platformer with some adventure elements thrown in. better than T2 Judgement Day, maybe not as good as the SNES The Mask? IDK. But I remember seeing image related in magazines advertising the SNES, NES and GameBoy games. the SNES was one of those common bargain bin games. I don't think i ever saw a NES box. More face buttons, better D-pad, etc. It probably should've had a second d-pad but in the late 90s/early 2000s that really didn't matter so much. The standard of left stick for movement and right stick for aiming hadn't really been solidified yet, even after the release of the dualshock. Using ABXY as a makeshift d-pad in games like MDK2 or unreal tournament wasn't ideal but it got the job done, and back then these types of games didn't need any more inputs than aim/move/jump/shoot anyway so it all worked out.

>>9625260
The Dual Analog only came out only 18 months before the Dreamcast and initially the second stick was just treated as a way to emulate the flight stick accessory.

>>9625319
As far as the right stick goes, I can't actually think of any PSX game that uses the right stick and doesn't just assume you aren't going to be actively using the face buttons. Like even in Gran Turismo you can use the right stick instead of X and Square and yeah Triangle and Circle are still reverse and e-brake, but you also aren't using the x-axis of the right stick at all so the total number of inputs still hasn't changed. So given that right stick camera control was unheard of in 1998 and thus using analog input both axes on the right stick was incredibly rare the Dreamcast having analog triggers was a good alternative.

On the flip side I can't defend going from 8 to 6 buttons, and being free from having to support the digital controller From was already making PS2 launch window games that used all 10 buttons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9630057
>>9630069
CD-R's are less reflective and have less data density. This usually makes the laser work more, however the biggest factor is that early scene releases of .cdi Dreamcast games had the files sorted alphabetically instead of in the original strategically placed order. Modern scene releases now sort files in the correct order. In some cases, such as PSOv2, the modern scene release is actually better for your laser. Sega fucked up on v2's character creation menu, so the laser has to repeatedly seek between the outer and inner part of the disc. In the end, the original discs are usually the best, but modern scene releases on CD-Rs are only a bit more strenuous.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9630235
>less data density
This is the only important consideration with Dreamcast, thank you for bringing this up. The GD-ROM is about 46% denser in bytes than a CD, so a GD doesn't have to spin as long for the same amount of bytes to be parsed. That said, for any system other than a Dreamcast, there will be no difference for the laser.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For me personally: Ape Escape, Jumping Flash 1 and 2, and Klonoa: Door to Phantomile are all extremely aesthetically pleasing and well thought out. I extend aesthetic to include the way the game presents through audio as well, all those games have such nice color choices, character design and environments alongside music that fits impeccably to the environments.
Klonoa especially has some of my favorite enemy designs ever. There's thid part in the forest world, where you have to walk a full U-Turn path that encircles a massive wooden gear - the first time you pass it, the enemies (iirc) are flying blue Moos - the second pass, once the gear is in motion, instead contains two very alien looking enemies that appear nowhere else in the game. I never knew why they did that when it seemed so arbitrary, but my instincts are they created something cool, wanted it in the game, and put them in just to do it, just for visual variety and to just kinda be noticed. I love things like that.
I guess all 3 games sort of represent that certain type of Japanese aesthetics and design where it captures all the high notes but without it being under the umbrella of anime. I like when games do that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625856
Thats how a lot of artists and creators were back then. Sometime around the 70's more fanboys ended up working in comics; and a lot of fields in general. There was a bit of a culture clash when a lot of old time comic guys had to deal with fanboys becoming creators and having reverence for stuff they had just seen as art. Steve Ditko, who created Spider-man, once got visited by a younger artist in the 90s and was shocked to see he was using old Spider-man pages as cutting board to cut new art. It would probably be worth alot today, but to him it was just old work.
You see the same thing in that infamous Oda interview where he's gushing about Dragonball to Toriyama and he's forgotten a lot of characters.

>He had a alot of spikey hair boys and straight hair girls with big eyes.

Look at Toriyama's other work and see how he's capable of doing other types of characters. Thing is, none of them are really the character types you see leading JRPGs or JP games in general. Toriyama is hired to draw young, cool, fit protagonists because they want characters that look like the DBZ Saiyans, not the schlubby townies of Dr. Slump. If Toriyama submitted designs that looked like, say, Tsun from Dr. Slump, who's a semi-realistic looking young guy(basically the template for Yamcha), I'm sure the Game developers would ask him to make him more dynamic and steer him to drawing more like Goku or Trunks.
Its a similar case with voice actors; very often voice directors will push VAs to do the same familiar voice instead of letting them branch out. Because that's what sells, and why they were hired.

When I trigger an event in the game, if it's reasonably obscure, it's possible that I'm the first person in the world to read it since the author.
That's crazy. It's like, I only started playing this because I wanted to sexually humiliate the female cast of Persona 3, and now I'm fulfilling the destiny of a story that's never been read.

>>9624769
They're different games.

Puyo 2 is the standard and the best version of it is on the Saturn, although Super Remix on the SNES is pretty good too.

N64 has two Puyo games, Sun and Yon. The former is decent and the second best game in the series though some people bitch about the Sun Puyo RNG. The latter killed Puyo though, adding character-specific abilities was a mistake and fucks up the balance.

And then lastly there's the original Puyo, which was reskinned into Mean Bean Machine and Kirby's Avalance. There's no real reason to play this version anymore since there's no offset rule which makes the gameplay far deeper and more exciting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9626949
Speaking as someone who went through this methodology I don't 100% support it but I did become literate in Japanese.
In my opinion the Anki decks are quite unnecessary. Mine hit me with words like 二十歳 in my first few days. I finally used that word for the first time in my entire life last week, eight fucking years after I was made to memorize it.
Real experience is better than flashcards in every way. I believe the best thing to do is to head into a VN immediately after learning kana.
That said, everyone learns differently, and I have met people who swear by Anki.

I'll be direct: if you love visual novels, learn Japanese.
Going from translated VNs to raw ones is like going from vitamin gummies to meth.
You think you love visual novels now?
Wait until you spend weeks, months getting to know a heroine, falling head over heels for her, and hearing her tell you in her own voice that she loves you too.
When everything finally clicked for me for the first time I turned into a fucking junkie. I would come home from work and do nothing but read VNs for four hours straight. Not because I was a workaholic, or committed to studying, but because it felt that fucking good.
When it's sweet it's ambrosia, it's eudaimonia. It's the best I've ever felt.
It certainly isn't always that good, and you have to put in a lot of work to get there, but you owe it to yourself to read a VN the real way at least once.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9614145
if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

posts.com:
in EU you should:

>put your starting base in Europe or North Africa which gives you the maximum # of funding countries covered
>start research on laser weapons immediately
>construct your base so the entrance lift is a choke point if the aliens raid it
>play sniper-spotter--don't shoot aliens with the guy who spotted them as he could get reaction shotted, use someone else
>never do nighttime crashed UFOs, there's no reason to not wait for morning

>>9618943

RT5X with CRT effect at 8:7 on a modest-but-not-large monitor with a little smudging to soften it slightly. it's not authentic with how it does the masks, but it's idealized for something that targets 1080p. the RT4K will do individual phosphor emulation.

alternatively, having a CRT of any kind that doesn't have fucked (mostly just asymmetry) geometry works. CRT shaders that emulate distortion often go way too far and exaggerate what would be minimized by calibration in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>It's a meme and only happens to faulty discs. The vast majority of discs are fine.

Objectively false. Bitrot is real. Burnable disks are not like retail pressed disks, they rely on an organic ink rather than physical pits, and that ink degrades over time. Your real PS1 games are likely going to outlive you unless you store them directly in the sun, but burned disks are going to fail, especially modern ones since only trash tier ones are still being manufactured anymore. I had Dreamcast and PS1 disks that failed in just a few years from various manufacturers.

But even poor quality retail disks can "rot", just in a different way, that's more an issue of the glue holding the layers together being poor quality and separating than the pits themselves degrading.

Also autocorrects suck

>>9621925
>It can take on a physical form, manifesting as weapons, armor, or sentient beings. The Maverick Virus behaves like an actual virus, spreading through physical space.
The Maverick Virus mutated from the Wily Virus, which was based on the Evil Energy that Wily found in Megaman 8.
According to Duo in MM8, the Evil Energy is actually a sapient alien substance that absorbs evil within robots minds and then multiplies as to infect more robots. Dr. Light found out that performing a full analysis of it was impossible (much like Zero's system). An entity made out of pure energy is an interesting concept since it can be a power source, be translated into electrical signals (and be transmitted as a virus) and even be converted into mass. Due to this method of replication, the original source can only be harnessed by beings of pure evil. The Wily virus made from it probably works in the same manner, "absorbing" Zero's destructive programming when he fought Sigma and had the migraines, and then spreading to Sigma and the rest of the reploids. Only someone who's pure evil could have it in their system and not die from it (like Wily in robot form).

That's why the Maverick Virus is so unorthodox and can do shit normal computer viruses can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the plot of X4 put plainly.

Repliforce was created to supplant the need to combat Mavericks due to the growing number of riots and rebellions perpetrated by Sigma and the virus, which the Hunters could barely control on their own, as evidenced in the past three X games. Repliforce's purpose was shown to be inefficient, and the Hunters were itching for a reason to disband them. Sigma noticed this, and began orchestrating the Sky Lagoon incident.

Magma Dragoon was a Maverick Hunter and prideful warrior who's always envied X's superior fighting abilities, believing the latter always hend back whenever they sparred during training sessions. This grudge he harbored against X allowed Sigma to convince him to sabotage Sky Lagoon and become a Maverick, all so he could force X to have a real fight with him, no holds barred. Still, Dragoon's motivation to betray the Maverick Hunters wasn't enough to cause the Repliforce war, as that would come later.

When the Sky Lagoon crashes, X and Zero find evidence of Repliforce presence in the rubble. They also find Colonel investigating the crash site, who claims to be looking for his sister Iris. The Hunters immediately demand him to surrender his weapons and follow them to the Hunter base for questioning (which often ends in imprisonment or decommission for Reploids, as someone has to take the fall until the real culprits are found, if ever. After all, the Maverick virus scare is a good enough prerogative to let the Hunters point fingers at just about anyone despite their own general ineffectiveness). The Maverick Hunters immediately grow suspicious when he refuses - the image of the second-in-command of Repliforce being detained would ruin public opinion on Repliforce and basically guarantee its dissolution through vox populi.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625818
The Hunters then demand General to disband the Repliforce and turn himself in for inquiry. Years of experience fighting Mavericks fueled the Hunters' concern that Repliforce could become dangerous, should they become infected by the Maverick Virus or grow strong enough to overpower the Hunters themselves.

The Hunters had a solid reason to be worried, but their authoritarian "do as we say or else" attitude was a big fucking insult to a man like General. Before the incident took place, Sigma warned him that this would happen sooner or later, as human beings were growing wary of armed Reploids running around (though General did not recognize Sigma during their meeting, since everyone thought he was dead for good). Sending a Repliforce representative to talk it out with the Hunters wouldn't work, since the Hunters wouldn't even give Colonel, General's right hand man, the time of day. General then decided that Repliforce should simply leave planet Earth and build a reploid colony in a space station. It wasn't a declaration of war so much as a "you don't trust us, so we're leaving" statement. The Hunters, of course, regarded their disobedience as Maverick behavior, and then the fighting began. The "Final Weapon" was originally the space station they wanted to move to, and was only turned into an actual weapon after the Hunters started going after Repliforce.

Even after the war begins, Repliforce officers like Jet Singray were shown evacuating the civilians before carrying out orders to destroy certain locations. Storm Owl's brigade was attacked by the Hunters, including X, who found himself acting just how Sigma wanted him to, when he denied Owl's accusation that the Hunters were corrupt, before executing him with a charged shot to the face.

Meanwhile, Double was sent by Sigma to Hunter base as to disrupt the flow of information and prevent any chance of peace accords between Repliforce and the Maverick Hunters from happening. And so you have Megaman X4.

>>9628239
Putting it into order it goes like this:
>Evil Energy -> Wily Virus (EE + robot reprogramming algorithm) -> Maverick Virus (Wily Virus optimized to explot Reploid design flaws) -> Sigma Virus (Maverick Virus fused with Sigma's digitized AI at the end of X1) -> Zero Virus (Sigma Virus fused with the virus smuggled by Dynamo into the Eurasia space colony and Zero's AI) -> Nightmare Virus (Zero Virus + DNA Program successfully reverse-engineered by Gate) -> Copy Chip (DNA Program of Sigma and many other old Reploids rendered inert and implemented into New Gen Reploids as to make use of the abilities it grants users)
It may sound silly in a work of fiction, but do remember how many strains of COVID we've gotten in like 3 years.
Putting this into perspective, EE being a sapient entitity does lend to the idea that it keeps consuming hosts and evolving much like a virus, jumping from robot to robot, system to system, mechaniloid to mechaniloid, iteration to iteration. Given the X series' overarching theme of robot free will, it does seem like the virus itself is acting on its own free will in a very twisted way, by rending others of their own.
If Wily turning himself into a cyborg holds true or at least plausible, the virus may have even taken over him. After all, his real body was never found. It may even hint at the reason why X and Zero are not allowed to go near the locations where their capsules were found.

You failed to mention Dreamcast has higher sampling quality for the sound effects + CD-quality music, a better bomb system that's based on destruction rather than collecting fruits (leading to faster and more dynamic gameplay), no shop system which slowed down the gameplay even more, and doesn't lag terribly like on N64. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622925
It seems you didn't read my post saying both are pretty different and both are worth playing, so I'm not saying DC one should be discarded, but I love this game so here we go
The bomb system on Dreamcast is actually more limited (you can only shoot as many missiles as there's enemies on screen), N64 lets you fire 100 missiles at a time, even if there's no enemy on screen. It's more chaotic and requires you to have better judgement on how to spend the missile bombing. Also, collecting fruit is pretty seamless and fast, as enemies leave fruit trails behind them, all you have to do is move acordingly and don't do any mistake while moving, and you can get the fruit on your way without any need for a detour.
The shop can be navigated within seconds, even split seconds. Or you can choose to not use the shop at all, if you don't want to.
Even if you want to argue that shooting with the face buttons is ideal (it's not IMO, and the devs agree), the C-buttons are more compact and act much better as a secondary d-pad than the DC's face buttons. However, the intended way to play Bangai O on the N64 is by using the d-pad to move and the stick to shoot. Might take some time to get used to it but once it clicked I could never go back to the face buttons.
Both versions are worth it, I think DC is better for beginners and N64 better for people who want more challenge. And thankfully both games offer enough changes, both gameplay wise and in presentación, that both are worth it and neither discarded.
By the way the music is different in both games, totally different conpositions.
I still don't know why are we discussing Bangai O on a co-op thread but hey, I love this game, wish it had a co-op mode.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9628910
This. The Getaway has a 1:1 recreation of inner London minus a lot of the smaller side streets. It's got licensed businesses that would've been in London circa 2002 as well as licensed cars such as Lexus, Toyota, Honda, Rover, Saab and a few more. I played it for the first time in 2022 and I'm astonished the GTA games caught as much attention as they did back in the day considering how much more focused and technically impressive The Getaway feels. GTA feels so cartoony and nerf and drawn out in comparison. The controls are somewhat jank but the atmosphere and story are very compelling. The Getaway Black Monday is a decent sequel with quality of life fixes but a less focused narrative and they lost a lot of the car licenses. Would recommend both.

And funny thing, in 2000, nobody would have batted at eyelid at that line of dialogue. I still own CV for the Dreamcast, and remember playing the game a week after it was released, and remember the 'cross dressing freak' line barely even registered with me. I was 19 at the time. It wasn't until more recent years when it became a bigger deal. Alfred was a freak and cross dressing as his sister.

The thing that always amused me about Resident Evil 2 and later Code Veronica personally, was that I could recognise Alyson Court's voice. back then I didn't really know her name, but I knew Claire was voiced by Jubilee from the Fox X-Men cartoon, and Llydia from the Beetlejuice cartoon. >Tony wants to lend Diddy Kong Racing to a friend at school

>Tony's friend plays the game and doesn't like it, I mean it's Diddy Kong Racing. He had lended OoT in return which he'd rather be playing, so as a thank you for feeling shafted, he write's 'S POOP on the cartridge under Tony's name, chuckles to himself, and gives the game back.
>Tony is furious but won't show it, so he has an idea.... and writes the last two words.

The rest is history.

posts.com:
I liked both CV64 and LoI.
64 is better in terms of experimenting and applying the CV franchise into 3D. The mix of platforming sections and more adventure, almost survival horror sections, the atmosphere, etc. It is a game I enjoy a lot, also props for having actual Vampire enemies other than Dracula, like regular villagers turned into vampires, that shit was cash.
Platforming is a bit weird, especially the ledge grabbing, but the combat is fine once you figure the dodge mechanic.
Lament it's true that it's repetitive, and has the metroidvania approach in 3D... but gameplay is decent (and I agree playing as the vampire boss with the blades was fun!), and it has some very nice looking locations, even if repetitive, and the OST is godly, some of Yamane's best.
Never played the other N64 game or Curse.

I was mulling over this a little today, and one thing that occurred to me is that I don't like the platforming in the N64 games just for the platforming itself and the gameplay; I feel it adds to the atmosphere and setting. Like, in the older games, whether it was demonically possessed, an embodiment of human evil, or just a run-down castle, it was a dangerous place, teeming with evil creatures, filled with traps if not just plain damn surrounded with noxious landscapes, run by a despicable monster of a man. The N64vanias really fill that for me.

I suppose technically, Lament and CoD have that, but they just don't execute well, not for me. Considering Walter's defining characteristic is being an ass and loving it, you'd think his castle wouldn't be so...flat.

Backlogs are dumb. If you just have like a small stack of games that you have and are playing through, that's fine. But backlog usually means "I have 100+ games I bought and didn't play but kept buying more anyway".

If it's gotten to that point, best to just disregard it. Don't add to it. From now on just buy one game, and play it to whatever amount satisfies your completionist autism or lack of. Then get another. As long as you don't add to your backlog it won't grow, and will only diminish, as over time you will whittle away at it as you occassionally do feel motivated to play this or that game from it instead of a new one.

>>9621756
>It got really stale after a while and my dad who was 7 at the time was too old for a lot of the overlay games
The overlay games were just a flop in general. There's a reason Magnavox' next console, the Odyssey 100, was just a slightly improved version of the original Odyssey (the ball would now bounce back if it hit the top or bottom of the screen) with no overlays or game cards to change the behavior of the ball and paddles - pretty much all Odyssey owners just played the table tennis "Pong" game and ignored all the other games that involved overlays and shit, so they could massively reduce cost by just leaving all that crap out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622512
Yeah, the original Odyssey was less "video game" and more like a box of board games with the Odyssey itself as the central component they were all designed around. It was after that they were able to zero in on what was actually fun about the thing and start building on that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622572
It took a while, really. Here's the Odyssey 100 in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZWPt8XHRUak

>still has the same general button setup as the Odyssey, with one dial for controlling vertical movement, one for controlling horizontal movement and one for controlling English per player, as well as one dial for controlling ball speed and one dial for controlling the position of the line
>the serve button has been removed, instead the player whose turn it is can serve the ball by touching the line (which actually gives it a gameplay function in the table tennis game instead of just being a visual indicator for where the rules said you "were allowed" to go, like on the original Odyssey. It still serves as such an indicator here though, the paddles can still go wherever they want on the screen and players need to police each other to follow the rules)
>the game still does not keep score, but now it has plastic sliders on the console to make it easier to keep count
>as mentioned, hitting the top or bottom of the screen will now make the ball bounce off, which probably feels a bit weird with the entire English paddle thing that otherwise gives you complete control over where the ball goes
>there's also a second selectable game, hockey, where the line gets a hole in the middle and needs to be placed at the left side of the screen, while a second, similar line will appear on the right side. Hitting the ball with these will have the same effect as if that player's paddle had hit it

It all looks and feels very very awkward and clumsy, not to mention extremely primitive compared to Atari's Pong consoles that WERE out at the time. They hadn't quite yet zeroed in on exactly what made Pong a better game than Odyssey Table Tennis.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9619631
The original is a very special game. Its well balanced, well designed and manages to be unnerving, despite the horrifically bad voice actors ruining the tone. It is somewhat archaic, which holds it back, but it's an easy 8/10

RE2 is an improvement in many ways, but it's troubled development shows. They basically just recreated the first game with different names for similar environments and mostly the same pacing and design reused.
That said, it's probably the best overall game of the original 3, as it perfects the formula of the original, adds in some good original concepts and has the best plot. 9/10

I have always seen RE3, Dino Crisis 2 and Onimusha as sister games, as they are all stabs at making action games out of traditional RE gameplay conventions.
RE3 is very repayable, fast paced and overall pretty fun, but it suffers from worse pacing and some optional backtracking being a pain in the ass due to how long it can take. It also feels more linear and takes place almost entirely on long, narrow paths. If it wasn't fun to play, it would score lower, but it's an 8/10 IMO

Code Veronica feels like a step backwards from 3 in terms of control and gameplay, it's not as well designed as 1 and 2, so it is basically just average feeling.
It has the least that sets it apart from the rest of the series. And it is the first entry to have an outright bad story. 7/10, but I'm being generous

REmake is an interesting animal. I feel like in terms of pacing and overall design, it's the ultimate survival horror game. But I also feel like it misses the mark as a remake. It's tonedeaf to what the original game was. It's also slower and the controls are more awkward than the first 4 games as well.
I adore it, but if it wasn't so pretty, most people wouldn't like it as much as they do. 8/10

Zero is another code veronica in many ways, except it manages to set itself apart with character zapping. 7.5/10

The reason RE4 exists the way it does is due to the development hell it went through, it originally started as RE3 back in 1998 after 2 concluded production, that's how bad it was. I've never seen CV officially referred to as the "real RE3" by Mikami though. Seems like the site is having issues loading the archive, but I have a screencap as well.
And 2 is a disappointment in direction, in the same interview Mikami also stated that he dislikes having what he called "1.9" being called 3. He sees these as iterations rather than evolutions.
>They got DMC out of is.
I mentioned that, but that isn't the promised "RE3" turned "RE4", which is a promise that is an extension of more ambitious ideas for RE2. REmake and 0 came out, but they were also just iterations on similar ideas and Zero itself also went through nearly 5 years of development, another waste of time production wise (especially considering they redid stretches of the narrative and content in the shift to GC). The spin-offs as well weren't anything major for Capcom and outside of Outbreak, they consistently underperformed (Outbreak 2 being the biggest bomb next to Dead Aim).
>Umbrella isn't in RE4
Wesker's already talking about bringing them back in the game.
>The stories don't make any fucking sense and are filled to the brim with retcons.
Such as? The biggest "retcon" of the early games were adding Marcus to the founders of Umbrella list (but they offer good reasoning for scrubbing his name from everything) and maybe Wesker being alive if you want to call it a retcon. Or I guess 3 retconned a few audio dramas due to poor communication.

posts.sub: Let's talk about Silent Hill 1 and 2
posts.com: Recently played through both these games and enjoyed them. I feel like 2 has the best sound design and story of the two, while 1 has better enemies, gameplay, and levels. What do you think about these games? Do you know any interesting facts or stories about these games?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623389
Silent Hill 1 is heavily entrenched in occult symbolism and esoteric lore. The basis of it's structure is that of alchemical transmutation. All of those key items you pick up in the final area aren't random--they represent key aspects that demonstrate your understanding and mastery of the occult ritual you had just underwent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: They wanted the town in Silent Hill 1 look American, obviously, but the interiors are all tiny like in Japan. That's your fun fact for the day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623389
Whenever I play them I always go back to the question of how to make resources work without an re style inventory slot limit and item box trip busywork, I don't think the SH games really succeed here, instead of having to consider resources for the entire game it just funnels your stockpiles into a handful of spongey lategame bosses which I don't think is all that engaging.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623389
>What do you think about these games?

1 felt deeply unnerving as kid, I never completed it. When I revisited it cca 10 years ago I found it to be a very interesting adventure game but I hated how easy it was to get the wrong ending. Mechanically it's so-so, very inferior to RE games which is also probably why I don't find myself wanting to replay it much. Its more of an experience than a straight up video game. 9/10

I also played 2 around the same time about 10 years ago or so and getting the In Water ending on the first run made quite an impression. I liked the game a lot and its atmosphere appealed to me more than the occult stuff from 1. Mechanically it's more of the same. One of the best games ever made.

3 I didn't like much at all. Already on the first run it felt very short and I didn't appreciate how action heavy it was. Protagonist did nothing for me and some of the segments (haunted house) felt very cheesy. Probably the least favorite in the series.

4 has arguably the best premise, setup and jumpscare in the series but the execution is absolute dogshit. Worth playing once but I'm never replaying it in this life.

Homecoming - better than expected. It has a suprisingly good atmosphere and its an okay enough horror game - especially if you consider what the genre became later on. It's enjoyable if you can stand some clunk and aren't a SH autist purist.

Origins - same as the above, in a classic SH package. In general I have to say that I enjoyed both Origins and Homecoming more than 3 and 4.

SM - only played the gimped PS2 version. It felt like a very comfy adventure game but the chase sequence ruined it for me. Worth playing once.

Didn't play Downpour.

Samael is actually from the pre-Christian Book of Enoch, which was very influential on second-Temple Jewish thought and early Christianity, but AFAIK he doesn't show up in any major Christian texts. In Enoch he is one of the Watchers, fallen angels who are synonymous with demons in Christianity. If you're interested in this kind of thing, you should check out the Dictionary of Demons and Deities in the Bible; it's an academic book that focuses on the original historical context of the writings rather than /x/-tier speculation.

Of course, they are easy and not really survival horror games. You have to play on hard just to have any challenge and it's still a very different experience compared to RE.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9623389
>Do you know any interesting facts or stories about these games?
SH1 (and the later games too, but it's especially impressive for a PS1 game) has uniquely intricate sound design. Ambient background music is comprised of multiple layers that change as you walk around - even within a single room. Almost feels like the music is some sort of natural background noise.
Health drinks are modelled after Japanese energy drinks. In SH1 the devs copied the design of Yunker Kotei DCF. In SH2 they copied Lipovitan.
The diner has an icon of Mary shedding blood tears.
The rusty Otherworld design is not a reference to the fire. It's a reference to the acid torture to which Alessa was subjected. You can find empty bottles of acid in the nightmare school.
Three keys that open the way to the school is a reference to the Dark Side of the Rainbow. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_Side_of_the_Rainbow The last track in The Dark Side of the Moon album is called Eclipse.
When you enter the male bathroom in the school, you can hear a girl crying in a stall. This might be a reference to Moaning Myrtle from Harry Potter (the 2nd book came out in 1998, SH1 was released early in 1999). Myrtle was bullied by her classmates and was killed by a Basilisk traveling through pipes. The school boss is a Basilisk like creature, and the pipes is a recurring theme in SH1 and SH3, mentioned by Ito in The Making Of: https://youtu.be/KiH4wOkSzGs?t=1191
The school storeroom has a large poster of what looks to be an autopsy photo. If Alessa saw that poster, this could explain the gore imagery in the game.

I played 3 on hard and it actually did a better job of making me feel tense and low on resources than any pretty much RE game except RE2R and maybe RE7, but as you mentioned a lot of that was down to having to save ammo for the bullet sponge bosses, which maybe isn't the right type of tension as it's more a dread of getting pseudo-softlocked and having to bash your head against the bosses over and over until you can melee them to death, which doesn't sound fun.

Still I'd take it over not having to worry about resources at all really like in SH1, although I still enjoyed exploring and solving puzzles in that game. Both of them do something I really hate in games though which is let you carry basically unlimited healing items that they let you use without any time cost. IMO you have to pick one, either really limit how many heals the player can access at once like RE, or make it so they actually have to complete some animation to use them. Otherwise you can just cheese things and tank your way through any parts that would give you trouble, I beat the final boss in SH1 by just immediately going into the menu whenever they hit me and spamming heals, then getting back to spamming the shoot button and repeating that over and over, which really wasn't any fun at all.

>>9624547
They thought it wouldn't be wise to have a game full of just speed - not only was that a part of US marketing only, but also playtesters were finding the speed so sickening that Green Hill had to be toned down. With this, they decided that the game should switch between fast zones and slow zones. They did intend the players to find ways to gain speed in any zone, as, for example, there are barely any sections where pushing blocks is actually required to proceed in Marble, and in Act 3, there's a large shortcut with rewards for finding it, but it's obvious that the pacing and design of Marble, Labyrinth and Scrap Brain are different from Green Hill, Spring Yard and Starlight.

>>9624547
going fast was a marketing thing more than a design thing. The game is more designed off of pinball than off of racing cars. Sometimes the ball moves quickly, other times the ball moves in a tricky way that must be mastered through practice and focus. That's why momentum is more important than speed. If you just make a sonic game with nothing but speed, you get the boost games.

As for complaints of repetition, it's an arcade game with levels designed in 1991. It's a home console from one of the biggest arcade devs and one that routinely designed games around practice and memorization being key toward being able to beat a game or to get a high score. What did you expect to be doing in this game? Idiots act like having to remember something about the game or having to practice the layouts makes it inherently bad. Next you'll complain about having to remember the controls too. If anything, you should be happy; Sonic is by far one of the easiest games Sega ever put out. It would be sad to see you try and beat games like Space Harrier on Hardest or Streets of Rage 2 on Mania. Those games have baby modes on them too, but recognize that their baby mode is basically the same as Sonic's difficulty, only sonic doesn't have adjustable settings so you're always stuck on Infantile.

Sonic was not about going fast all the time.
Going fast was for mastering the level design and finding the more rewarding routes. If you look at the levels, most of them have multi paths, usually the lower path is the noob path, and the higher paths are the get good paths, that require to use the speed, coupled with a good understanding of the game physics, to reach. Those are usually full of rings, 1ups and other p-ups.

And then there is curling into a ball, which as already stated, Marble zone is about. But Marble Zone is also a way to teach the player the physics, you have to understand how it works slow before you can take it fast.

At least that's what OP's mom says.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625586
>There's nothing foregone about something like that.
Let's take a look at Resident Evil for a second.

The first game is a murder mystery in a big and weird mansion overrun with zombies and monsters, you need to find out who's the traitor, and then save who you can and get out. Second game, there's now an outright outbreak of zombies and monsters in the city, you're barricaded in big police precinct which used to be a bizarre art gallery, and you need to root out the traitors and save who you can. With the third game, the situation in the city is untenable and those who survived have to flee before the place gets bombed flat to contain the outbreak.
The fourth game goes onto its own story, which has some separation from the earlier titles, but there's a running plot thread from the previous ones which ties into it, and it's very obviously meant to set up some sort of conclusion for a future entry.

Resident Evil is, overall, not that well written, not that deep, and it's clear that there's barely an idea for where the overarching story was heading. However, the story actually does progress, the first three games are about making your escape, essentially, but throughout this it's also about trying to find some answers and some evidence regarding the Umbrella Corporation, which are responsible, and this ends up being concluded in the fifth game. VERY poorly, even by the standards of a series which wasn't well written and which was fumbling in the dark for an overarching plot, but nonetheless there was one and it was building towards something.

Zelda doesn't. It's a new Link every time, a new worldmap, a new Zelda, and a new Ganon, and Link has to go save Zelda from Ganon. This is always the case, it's practically like most games are a reboot of the last one, there's no overarching anything at all in terms of story, it's always starting over.
There's virtually NEVER been anything to suggest otherwise for Zelda, hence why your disappointment baffles me.

>>9625837
>Zelda doesn't. It's a new Link every time, a new worldmap, a new Zelda, and a new Ganon, and Link has to go save Zelda from Ganon. This is always the case, it's practically like most games are a reboot of the last one, there's no overarching anything at all in terms of story, it's always starting over.
>There's virtually NEVER been anything to suggest otherwise for Zelda, hence why your disappointment baffles me.

Up through Wind Waker/TP there's a lot of elements int he main games that tease a linked narrative. We know LoZ/AoL take place at a time where a past Zelda existed, and there are multiple Zeldas thanks to the manual. Then in LTTP, we know it takes place before the first two games. In OoT, we see the sages have names that tie into town names in AoL, which implies a tie there. We see the OoT link as a staue in Windwaker, and the whole story of Ganon returning and winning seemed to tie into Link disappearing in MM to another world.
So I don't see what's so unbelievable about people thinking there was some grand plan.
